card.question: Rich Mr. Dashwood dies, leaving his second wife and her daughters poor by the rules of inheritance

Mr. and Mrs. Bennet have five unmarried daughters, and Mrs. Bennet is especially eager to find suitable husbands for them. When the rich single gentlemen Mr. Bingley and Mr. Darcy come to live nearby, the Bennets have high hopes. But class differences and misunderstandings combine to complicate their relationships and to make happiness difficult.
At age 10, Fanny Price is sent by her destitute mother to live with her aunt and uncle. Her love for her cousin a prevents her from accepting a proposal of marriage.
A young woman has a rigid sense of propriety as regards matrimonial alliances. Unfortunately she insists on matchmaking for her less forceful friend, and so causes her to come to grief.

Catherine Morland, staying with a childless family, is hoping for an adventure of the type she has been reading in novels. Invited to visit an estate of a handsome young man, she has thoughts of romance but soon learns that status, class and money are all equally important when it comes to matters of the heart.
A young woman breaks off her engagement with a poor naval officer at the insistence of her family. Meeting him later in life, they are reconciled.
